questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with right sided parotid swelling. CT scan showed involvement of only superficial lobe of parotid gland. Patient underwent superficial parotidectomy. On histopathological examination the tumour showed presence of glandular and cystic structure lined by bilateral epithelium, the stroma contains lymphoid tissue with germinal centres. Picture Is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Warthin's tumour is the second most common benign tumour of the salivary glands after pleomorphic adenoma.

Histopathological examination of warthin's tumour shows prominent germinal centres. The stroma contains lymphoid tissue. The tumour is often glandular and cystic in nature lined by characteristic bilateral epithelium comprising inner columnar surrounded by smaller basal cells.

It commonly affects men in their sixth or seventh decades of life. Multicystic appearance with bilateral involvement is common.

Adenoid Cystic carcinoma has ductal and Modified myoepithelial cells. They have hyperchromatic and angular nuclei and frequently clear cytoplasm. Marked nuclear pleomorphism is seen. Ki -67 immunostaining is a helpful immuno marker. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Warthin:

  • Elderly male
  • Biphasic - Lymphoid tissue & Bilayer epithelium.
  • Mx - Superficial parotidectomy

Image reference: Pathology outlines website.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient was undertaken for submandibular gland excision on right side. The specimen was sent for histopathology examination which revealed presence of ductal and myoepithelial cells, hyperchromatic nucleus. Perineural and intraneural invasion is also seen. Picture Is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis based on it?
questions.solution:
Perineural and intraneural invasion is a common feature of Adenoid cystic carcinoma.

ACC is a basaloid tumor containing epithelial and myothelial components with tubular, solid and cylindrical patterns.

It is a slow growing but a highly malignant neoplasm. Pain is a common feature due to Perineural invasion.

Microscopically it contains ductal and Modified myoepithelial cells. They have hyperchromatic and angular nuclei and frequently clear cytoplasm. Marked nuclear pleomorphism is seen. Ki -67 immunostaining is helpful immuno marker.

Key Takeaway :

Adenoid Cystic carcinoma

  • Perineural invasion
  • Contains ductal & modified myoepithelial cells.
  • Ki67 Immunostaining

Image reference: Pathology outlines website.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with complain of swelling over parotid region since 2 months. CT scan shows mass inside the superficial lobe of parotid gland. The mass had irregular borders, blurred margins and inhomogeneous structure. There is also presence of lymph node with central necrosis. CT picture shown below what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Computed tomography features of malignant salivary neoplasm, especially advanced cases include an irregular shape, irregular borders, blurred margins, and inhomogeneous structure.

High vascularization and high systolic peak flow should raise the suspicion of malignancy.

Doppler USG does not allow reliable differentiation between benign and malignant salivary gland tumor. The presence of metastatic appearing lymph node with Central necrosis strongly suggests malignancy.

Ultrasound also shows irregular shape, borders, and a hypoechoic inhomogeneous structure.

The most common malignant neoplasms occurring in salivary glands are Mucoepidermoid carcinoma and adenoid cystic carcinoma.

Key takeaway :

Computed tomography features of malignant salivary neoplasm, especially advanced cases, include an irregular shape, irregular borders, blurred margins, and inhomogeneous structure.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with complain of swelling over neck since 2 months. On examination it was pushing the lateral wall of oropharynx and tonsils medially. A parapharyngeal space tumor is suspected. MRI suggestive of tumor displacing Internal carotid artery anteriorly. Tumor is hyper intense on T2 and shows smooth widening of skull foramen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Key takeaway :

When schwannoma grows, it causes smooth widening of skull foramen, Displace ICA anteriorly which are seen as hyperintense on T2-weighted image.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient known case of malignant condition of salivary gland. She underwent submandibular gland excision. His post operative histopathology showed the presence of squamous, mucus and basaloid cells. The squamous cells form solid nests. The mucous cells form solid masses or line cysts. Mucin stains were positive. Picture given below. What is the most probable diagnosis based on this?
questions.solution:
The microscopic picture of Mucoepidermoid carcinoma includes:

The most common cell type present are squamous cells, mucus cells cuboidal cells and basaloid cells.

The squamous cells form solid nests and it’s component often predominates in high-grade tumors.

The mucous cells form solid masses or line cysts. They predominate in low grade tumors.

Intermediate cells are usually small with dark-staining nuclei but can be larger with a clear cytoplasm.

Clinical features: slow-growing tumor painless growth. Well circumscribed. Mostly seen in parotid gland, sometimes in submandibular gland. Mixed epidermis and mucus secreting carcinoma.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient known case of pleomorphic adenoma of parotid gland. He was undertaken for a superficial parotidectomy. The main trunk of the facial nerve lies how deep to the tragal pointer?
questions.solution:
The lower end of the tragal cartilage is one of the landmark to identify facial nerve during superficial parotidectomy. The facial nerve main trunk lies 1 cm medial and inferior to the tip of the pointer.

Steps of superficial parotidectomy includes:

  • Preparation: many surgeons Use intraoperative facial nerve monitor. Mainly in large tumors and recurrent surgery.
  • Incision: The standard incision is Modified Blair's incision. The incision begins from pretragal skin crease, extends around the ear lobule, gently curving down two fingers breadth below the mandible.
  • Flap elevation: skin flap should be raised superficial to parotid fascia and in neck sub platysmally.
  • Identification of facial nerve: The various landmark are: Tragal pointer- The nerve lies 1 cm medial and below the pointer, Tympanomastoid suture line, superior portion of posterior belly of digastric nerve, posterior auricular artery, styloid process.

Key takeaway:

The facial nerve main trunk lies 1 cm medial and inferior to the tip of the pointer.

Image reference: Operative technique in otolaryngology website.

choices.text: Donut sign, internal carotid artery thrombosis

questions.text: A 19-year-old female patient presented with a swelling in the neck at the level of thyroid cartilage. On examination swelling was pulsatile and compressible, which often rapidly refills on releasing of pressure. Angiography of large neck vessels was performed picture is shown below. Identify the sign depicted in the picture and what is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is carotid angiography which shows

Mass at the bifurcation of internal and external carotid artery. It leads to splaying of internal and external carotid artery which is known as lyre's sign. Presence of this sign is suggestive of carotid body tumor.

Angiography is diagnostic of carotid body tumor.

Small tumors in young patients can be resected. Radiotherapy is proffered in elderly patients or extensive tumors in high risk patients.

Arterial embolization Aids in clearance of large tumors with less blood loss.

Option A: The target sign of neurofibromatosis is a lesional pattern of T2 signal on MRI Consisting of a central area of low intensity that is surrounded by T2 Hyperintense Rim.

Option B: Donut sign is seen in carotid artery thrombosis in the axial plane in CT angiography.

Option D: Salt & Pepper Chromatin appearance is seen in Histopathology of Schwannoma.

Key Takeaway:

Mass at the bifurcation of internal and external carotid arteries leads to splaying of internal and external carotid arteries which is known as lyre's sign. Presence of this sign is suggestive of carotid body tumor.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presented with complain of swelling in the neck at level 1b and level 2. MRI of this patient was done which showed presence of swelling in the pre styloid part of Para pharyngeal space. The mass had well defined margins and it is bright on T2 weighted image. It was intermittent on T1 image. The picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given findings of MRI the most probable diagnosis is pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma appears in the prestyloid space of the parapharyngeal space. It has well defined margins and is bright on T2 and intermittent on T1 imaging.

Option A: Malignant tumors have irregular margins, displaces ICA posteriorly. Fat surrounding the tumor.

Option C: Schwannoma displaces ICA anteriorly smooth widening of skull foramen is seen. T2 is hyperintense.

Option D: Cystic hygroma is intense on both T1 and T2.

Key Takeaway:

Pleomorphic adenoma appears in the prestyloid space of the parapharyngeal space. It has well defined margins and is bright on T2 and intermittent on T1 imaging.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: Lower level of margin of jugular fossa
Vertical plane defined by accessory nerve
Level of lower body of hyoid bone

questions.text: All of the following are the boundaries of level 2a neck level except?
questions.solution:
Posterior border of sternocleidomastoid is a part of level 2b neck node region and not part of level 2a region so option D is wrong .

Boundaries of level 2a neck node region are :

  • Superiorly by Lower level of margin of jugular fossa. ( Option A )
  • Posteriorly by Vertical plane defined by accessory nerve. ( Option B )
  • Inferiorly by Level of lower body of hyoid bone. ( Option C )
  • Anteriorly by Posterior border of stylohyoid muscle.

Boundaries of level 2b neck node region are:

  • Superiorly Lower level of margin of jugular fossa.
  • Anteriorly Vertical plane defined by accessory nerve.
  • Inferiorly Level of lower body of hyoid bone.
  • Posterior: Posterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Key Takeaway:

Boundaries of level 2a neck node region are :

  • Superiorly By Lower level of margin of jugular fossa.
  • Posteriorly by Vertical plane defined by accessory nerve.
  • Inferiorly by Level of lower body of hyoid bone.
  • Anteriorly by Posterior border of stylohyoid muscle.

choices.text: Posterior border of the sterno cleido mastoid muscle
Inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle
Middle one third of the clavicle

questions.text: All of the following structures forms the boundaries of the Level 5 a lymph node level of neck except?
questions.solution:
Middle one third of the clavicle forms the inferior border of level 5 b and not of level 5 a so option D is not true.


Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Near the lower pole of thyroid gland in case of anterior displacement
Point of crossing of inferior thyroid artery
At the point of entry to cricothyroid joint

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient underwent thyroidectomy. Recurrent laryngeal nerve is encountered during the surgery. All of The following are the common sites of injury to nerve during the surgery except?
questions.solution:
The recurrent laryngeal nerve run in or lateral to the tracheoesophageal groove. It has a variable relation with the branches of inferior thyroid artery.

On the left side, the nerve hugs the tracheoesophageal groove as it ascends from the chest. However on the right side the nerve is more superficial being 45 degree to the tracheoesophageal groove.

The three most common sites of injury are:

  • Near the lower pole in case of anterior displacement (Option A)
  • At The point of entry of nerve Near cricothyroid joint. (Option C)
  • At the point of crossing of inferior thyroid artery. (Option B)

Surgical landmark of the recurrent laryngeal nerve is the Baehr's triangle. It is formed by common carotid artery inferiorly, inferior thyroid artery laterally and recurrent laryngeal nerve medially.

Key Takeaway:

MC sites of RLN Injury

  • Near the Lower pole
  • Near Cricothyroid Joint
  • At Crossing of Inferior Thyroid artery.

choices.text: It induces genetic damage by forming covalent binds with DNA adducts through the genome including p53
Inactivation of TP53 gene by E6 protein and E7 protein inactivates the retinoblastoma gene product

questions.text: Which of the following statements shows the mechanism of carcinogenesis by the human papilloma virus strain no 16 and 18?
questions.solution:
Key Takeaway:

HPV acts via Inactivation of TP53 & RB gene by E6 & E7 Protein Respectively.

choices.text: Lower level of bony margin of jugular fossa
Lower level of body of hyoid bone
Vertical plane formed by spinal accessory nerve

questions.text: A 40-year-old male underwent selective neck dissection. Surgeon was dissecting neck lymph node level 2b. All of the following structures forms the boundaries of level 2b except?
questions.solution:
Stylohyoid muscle forms the Anterior boundary of level 2a and not of level 2b


Key Takeaway:

Boundaries of level 2 b neck node region are :

  • Superiorly Lower level of margin of jugular fossa.
  • Anteriorly Vertical plane defined by accessory nerve.
  • Inferiorly Level of lower body of hyoid bone.
  • Posterior: Posterior border of sternocleidomastoid muscle.

choices.text: Preserves spinal accessory nerve, internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle
Preserves spinal accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
Preserves spinal accessory and sternocleidomastoid muscle

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma buccal mucosa with involvement of mandible underwent wide local excision, Hemi mandibulectomy and Type 1 Modified radical neck dissection. Which of of the following structures are preserved in type 1 Modified radical neck dissection?
questions.solution:
Radical neck dissection: it involves removal of level 1 to 5 cervical lymph nodes, it also includes removal of all the three structures spinal accessory nerve, internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Modified radical neck dissection: it includes removal of level 1 to 5 cervical lymph nodes but one, two or all three nonlymphatic structures are preserved. It was introduced to reduce the morbidity created in radical neck dissection. They are of 3 types


Selective neck dissection: it involves preservation of all three: spinal accessory nerve and internal jugular vein and sternocleidomastoid muscle. Over and above that, it also preserves one or more group of lymph nodes.

Key Takeaway:

MRND Types: Preserve NVM

  1. Preserve XI Nerve
  2. Preserve XI Nerve & IJV
  3. Preserve XI Nerve, IJV & SCM

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma buccal mucosa was undertaken for neck dissection. During surgery, lymph nodes from level 1, 2, 3 and 4 regions are removed. What is the type of selective neck dissection done in this case?
questions.solution:
Selective neck dissection involves preservation of one or more nodal levels, which is removed in radical neck dissection along with preservation of sterno cleido mastoid muscle, spinal accessory nerve and internal jugular vein

Types of SND includes

Supra omohyoid neck dissection: level 1, 2 and 3 are removed. ( Option A )

Extended supra omo hyoid neck dissection here level 4 is also removed. ( Option B )

Lateral neck dissection level 2,3 and 4 are removed. ( Option C )

Anterior Lateral neck dissection: level 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 are removed. ( Option D )

PosteroLateral neck dissection: level 2, 3, 4 and 5 are removed.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with an ulceroproliferative lesion measuring 3 cm in left buccal mucosa. He also had an enlarged lymph node on right side submandibular region. Size of the lymph node was about 5cm. Clinically, there was no evidence of distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging ?
questions.solution:
Since size of primary tumour comes between 2cm to 4cm the T staging will be T2. And since lymph node size is between 3 to 6 cm and contralateral node is involved the N stage will be N2c.As per the T staging of oral cavity cancer

Tis: Describes a stage called carcinoma (cancer) in situ. This is a very early cancer where cancer cells are found only in 1 layer of tissue.

T1: The tumour is 2 cm or less at its greatest dimension. The tumour has invaded nearby tissues to a depth of 5 mm or less; this is called depth of invasion.

T2: The tumour is 2 cm or smaller, and the depth of invasion is more than 5 mm. Or, the tumour is larger than 2 cm but not larger than 4 cm, and the depth of invasion is 10 mm or less.

T3: The tumour is larger than 2 cm but not larger than 4 cm, and the depth of invasion is more than 10 mm. Or, the tumour is larger than 4 cm with a depth of invasion 10 mm or less.

T4: This is moderately advanced or very advanced local disease.

  • T4a (lip): The tumor began on the lip but has invaded bone or spread to the inferior alveolar nerve in the mouth, the floor of the mouth, or the skin of the face.
  • T4a (oral cavity): The tumor is larger than 4 cm, and the depth of invasion is more than 10 mm. Or, the tumor has invaded nearby structures in the mouth, such as the jaw, sinuses, or skin of the face.
  • T4b: The tumor has invaded the muscles and bones that form the mouth or the base of the skull, and/or it encases the internal arteries.
  • N0 (N zero): There is no evidence of cancer in the regional lymph nodes.
  • N1: The cancer has spread to a single lymph node on the same side as the primary tumor, and the cancer found in the node is 3 cm or smaller. There is no ENE.
  • N2a: Cancer has spread to a single lymph node on the same side as the primary tumor and is larger than 3 cm but not larger than 6 cm. There is no ENE.
  • N2b: Cancer has spread to more than 1 lymph node on the same side as the primary tumor, and none measures larger than 6 cm. There is no ENE.
  • N2c: Cancer has spread to more than 1 lymph node on either side of the body, and none measures larger than 6 cm. There is no ENE.
  • N3a: The cancer is found in a lymph node and is larger than 6 cm. There is no ENE.
  • N3b:There is ENE in any lymph node.

AJCC Table:


Key Takeaway:

N2 Staging Summary:

  • N2A - Size < 6 cm
  • N2B - Multiple Ipsilateral.
  • N2C - Contralateral

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient is a known case of carcinoma Nasopharynx. His CT Scan was performed which shows tumor with infiltration of bony structure at skull base, sphenoid sinus and pterygoid structures. It has a unilateral cervical node of 4cm in diameter. No evidence of distant metastasis. What is the staging of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) Stage 0: T1s-N0-M0

B) Stage I: T1-N0-M0

C) Stage II: T1-N1-M0 and T2-N0, N1-M0

D) Stage III: T1, T2, T3-N2-M0 and T3-N0, N1, N2-M0

E) Stage IVA: T4-any N-M0 and Any T, N3-M0

F) Stage IVB: Any T-any N, M1.


Key Takeaway:

Summary:

  • If M1 - 4b
  • If N3 / T4 - 4a
  • If N2 / T3 - 3

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is a known case of T1 N0M0 squamous cell carcinoma of oropharynx. He underwent radiotherapy for the same. After 3 months of completion of RT residual disease was found in the patient. What will be the further line of management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Regular follow up is sufficient in complete response to radiotherapy.

Option B: Chemoradiation is required if adverse factors are present post surgical management.

Option C: Repeat Radiotherapy has no role in management of residual disease.

Key Takeaway:

In Oral Carcinoma, Post Radiotherapy Residual disease is treated with Salvage Surgery & Follow up.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma buccal mucosa came to OPD. His CT Scan shows tumor of 3cm in maximum dimension. The tumor also shows 7mm depth of invasion. There was no cervical lymph node enlargement. What will be the stage of this tumor as per TNM staging?
questions.solution:
a. TX: primary tumour cannot be assessed

b. Tis: carcinoma in situ

c. T1: tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension with depth of invasion (DOI) ≤5 mm

d. T2

  1. tumor ≤2 cm with DOI >5 mm and ≤10 mm, or
  2. tumor >2 cm and ≤4 cm with DOI ≤10 mm

e. T3

  1. any tumor with DOI >10 mm, or
  2. tumor >4 cm with DOI ≤10 mm

f. T4: moderately or very advanced

  • T4a: moderately advanced local disease:
    1. tumor >4 cm with DOI >10 mm, or
    2. tumor invades adjacent structures (e.g. through cortical bone of mandible or maxilla, into the maxillary sinus, into the skin of face)*
  • T4b: very advanced local disease:
    1. tumor invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, or skull base, and/or
    2. tumor encases the internal carotid artery.

stage 0

a. Tis, N0, M0

stage I

b. T1, N0, M0

stage II

c. T2, N0, M0

stage III

d. T3, N0, M0

e. [T1, T2, T3], N1, M0

stage IVA

f. T4a, [N0, N1], M0

g. [T1, T2, T3, T4a], N2, M0

stage IVB

h. [Any T], N3, M0

i. T4b, [Any N], M0

stage IVC

j. [Any T], [Any N], M1.


Key Takeaway:

T2 Stage (Tumor Size 2-4 cm ) without Lymph Node and Metastasis is also Tumor stage 2.

Image reference: Pathology outlines website.

choices.text: Main management in this case is excision with a margin of 4 to 5 mm and deep margins to the fat
It is a highly radio resistant tumour
It is a slow growing tumour

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with complain of non-healing ulcer between nose and upper lip. The ulcer had raised margins with a rolled out edge and Central ulceration. This is known as rodent ulcer. Picture Is given below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Based on clinical findings and picture, the diagnosis in this case is Basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma is highly radio sensitive and not radio resistant. ( Option B )

It is one of the common skin cancer arising from basal cell keratinocytes. It has 5 subtypes nodular, superficial, basosquamous, pigmented and morpheme. Nodular is the most common type. ( Option C )

Clinical features: They are slow growing tumour. ( Option D ) They commonly occur on nose, nasolabial region, upper lip, columella. It appears as a raised lesion with a rolled edge, telangiectasic and Central ulceration constituting the features of classic rodent ulcer.

Diagnosis: it is mainly diagnosed by history, physical examination, biopsy.

Management: Non surgical : topical imiquimod cream, topical 5 FU, photodynamic therapy or cryotherapy.

Surgical: it is the best option, excision with a margin of 4 to 5 mm and deep margins down to the fat. The larger lesions should be considered for Moh's microscopic surgery for meticulous assessment. ( Option A )

As Tumor is highly radiosensitive can be used as an alternative to surgery in elderly patient.

Key Takeaway:

BCC

  • Slow growing Tumor
  • 5 histological subtypes
  • Rx : Excision with 5 mm margin / Radiotherapy

Image reference: The Australasian college of dermatologist website.

choices.text: Submental branch of the facial artery
Angular branch of the facial artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma buccal mucosa underwent wide local excision. The reconstruction of the defect created after surgery was done using a local flap. Picture Is given below. This flap receives blood supply from which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
The flap shown in the picture above is the nasolabial flap. It is a type of local flap which is based on angular branch of the facial artery.

Local flaps: They may be rotational, advancements transposition. Since the vascularity of the head and neck region is excellent, longer flaps with a narrow pedicle can be safely raised.

  • Nasolabial flap: it is raised from nasolabial crease and is based upon Angular branch of facial artery. It can be superiorly or inferiorly based. It is commonly used for nasal and intraoral defects. (OptionB)
  • Submental flaps: it is a flap from submental area which is based upon the submental branch of the facial artery. It is used for defects of floor of the mouth and lower third of the face. (Option A)
  • Forehead flap: The median forehead flap is based upon the supra orbital artery. It is used to resurface the defect of dorsum of nose. (Option C)

Key takeaway:

Nasolabial flap: it is raised from nasolabial crease and is based upon Angular branch of facial artery. It can be superiorly or inferiorly based. It is commonly used for nasal and intraoral defects.

Image reference: people's journal of scientific research.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient known case of carcinoma buccal mucosa underwent wide local excision of the primary lesion with neck dissection. The defect created after wide local excision was large so Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap was used in the reconstruction. Picture given below. This flap is based on which blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap is considered as the workhorse of the oral cavity reconstruction.

This flap is based on the Thoracoacromial vessels. This vessel runs beneath the Pectoralis major muscle at the midpoint of clavicle.

The flap can provide coverage of the middle and lower third of the face, the neck and the oral cavity.

Excess bulk, non pliability , and donor site deformity are the chief drawbacks of this flap.

Key Takeaway:

Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap is considered as the workhorse of the oral cavity reconstruction. This flap is based on the Thoracoacromial vessels. This vessel runs beneath the Pectoralis major muscle at the midpoint of clavicle .

Image reference: Science direct.com

choices.text: Anterior tibial vessels and regional flap
Dorsalis pedis vessels and free flap

questions.text: Fibular flap is commonly used for reconstruction of defects of Hemi mandibulectomy. This flap is based on which of the following artery. What is type of this flap?
questions.solution:
The fibular flap is an example of a free flap, which means that in this type of flaps the donor site and recipient sites are distant from each other and the flap carries it's blood vessels along with it.

Fibular flap is based on peroneal vessels. The fibular flap provides good bone stock and it's robust peroneal supply ensures that multiple osteotomies can be performed.

The flexor hallucis longus muscle and skin can be harvested along with the flap to provide soft tissue reconstruction along with the bone. Up to 25 cm of bone can be harvested.

Key takeaway:

The fibular flap is an example of free flap which means that in this type of flaps the donor site and recipient sites are distant from each other and the flap carries it's blood vessels along with it. Fibular flap is based on peroneal vessels.
